question: Which statements correctly describe a Type I (specified head) boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Type I specifies head; the resulting flux follows from the solution and can represent regulated surface water bodies.
error: ❌ Not quite. Remember: Type I sets head (not flow). The resulting flux can be completely implausible but doesnt affect the boundary head.

question: Which statements correctly describe a Type II (specified flux) boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Type II prescribes flux (e.g., recharge, pumping); head is computed to satisfy that flux.
error: ❌ Some choices are off. Type II sets flux, not head; head responds to meet the flux requirement.

question: Which statements correctly describe a Type III (head-dependent flux) boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Type III uses conductance to relate head difference to flux; C→0 implies vanishing exchange.
error: ❌ Not quite. Recall: q = C(h - H); only infinite C approaches defined head.

question: How do the three boundary types relate to the mathematical formulation of the groundwater flow equation? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Type I fixes the variable (head), Type II fixes its derivative (flux), and Type III links both through conductance.
error: ❌ Remember: Type I = fixed head, Type II = fixed flux, Type III = head–flux relationship (conductance).

question: Which scenarios are suitably represented by a Type III boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Streams, wells with skin effect, and drains are head-dependent; a perfectly constant stage in direct contact with the groundwater can be represented by type I.
error: ❌ Reconsider: head-dependent processes (via conductance/resistance) point to type III, not a fixed stage.

question: Regarding conductance in head-dependent boundaries (like rivers, drains), which statements are correct? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! C ∼ K·A/ΔL; lower C → less exchange; C→∞ approximates fixed head.
error: ❌ Not quite. Conductance reflects leakiness (K·A/ΔL), not a head unit.

question: Consider a model with uniform recharge, a no-flow boundary on the left, and a Type I boundary on the right. Which statements are true? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! No‑flow blocks discharge; uniform recharge enters over the surface; outflow is to the right.
error: ❌ Review: no‑flow does not allow flux; recharge is distributed, not a point load.

question: Which elements are typically considered as a type 1 boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct! Elements with (relatively) well known head that are in contact with the groundwater can be considered as type 1 boundaries.
error: ❌ Neither observation wells with point measurements nor abstraction wells are typically considered as type 1 boundaries.
